items.text: I am a born leader and people naturally follow my direction.
items.rationale: Directly reflects belief in one's natural leadership capacity, a core facet of Authority.

items.text: I feel most comfortable when I am the one making decisions for the group.
items.rationale: Preference for decision-making control is central to the Authority dimension.

items.text: People always seem to look to me for guidance in difficult situations.
items.rationale: Perception that others defer to one's leadership maps clearly to Authority.

items.text: I have a natural talent for influencing people and getting them to see things my way.
items.rationale: Belief in one's persuasive power and influence over others is a hallmark of Authority.

items.text: I would make a great leader if given the chance to run things.
items.rationale: Confidence in one's leadership potential directly taps the Authority factor.

items.text: When I walk into a room, I expect people to pay attention to what I have to say.
items.rationale: Expectation of commanding attention in social settings reflects authoritative self-perception.

items.text: I see myself as someone who is destined to be in charge.
items.rationale: A sense of destiny regarding leadership roles is a core Authority belief.

items.text: I enjoy organizing people and directing their activities.
items.rationale: Taking pleasure in directing others is a behavioral expression of Authority.

items.text: Others describe me as someone who takes charge without being asked.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of spontaneous leadership behavior maps to Authority.

items.text: I feel uneasy when someone else is leading a project I'm involved in.
items.rationale: Discomfort with relinquishing control reflects the need for authority and dominance.

items.text: I know that I am a good leader because people tell me so all the time.
items.rationale: Using social validation to confirm leadership identity is characteristic of Authority.

items.text: I have a strong desire to hold positions of power and responsibility.
items.rationale: Explicit desire for power and responsibility is definitionally tied to Authority.

items.text: People who know me would say I have a commanding presence.
items.rationale: A commanding presence could relate to Authority but also to Exhibitionism or Superiority.

items.text: I tend to dominate conversations because I usually know the most about the topic.
items.rationale: Dominating conversations could reflect Authority but also touches on Superiority through perceived intellectual dominance.

items.text: I believe I am more capable of leading than most people around me.
items.rationale: While leadership confidence maps to Authority, the comparative judgment of being more capable than others overlaps with Superiority.

items.text: I deserve special treatment because of who I am.
items.rationale: Belief that one inherently deserves special treatment is the defining feature of Entitlement.

items.text: I expect people to go out of their way to accommodate my needs.
items.rationale: Expecting others to prioritize one's needs is a direct expression of Entitlement.

items.text: If I don't get the recognition I deserve, I feel genuinely angry.
items.rationale: Anger at perceived insufficient recognition reflects entitled expectations.

items.text: Rules that apply to other people shouldn't necessarily apply to me.
items.rationale: Believing oneself to be exempt from common rules is a classic Entitlement indicator.

items.text: I get frustrated when I have to wait in line like everyone else.
items.rationale: Irritation at being treated like an ordinary person reflects entitled expectations.

items.text: I honestly feel that I am just more deserving than other people.
items.rationale: Explicit belief in being more deserving is the core of the Entitlement construct.

items.text: When things don't go my way, I feel like I've been treated unfairly.
items.rationale: Interpreting undesirable outcomes as unfair treatment reflects an entitled worldview.

items.text: I expect a great deal from other people and I rarely feel they deliver.
items.rationale: Chronically high expectations of others with frequent disappointment maps to Entitlement.

items.text: I shouldn't have to do menial tasks—those are beneath someone like me.
items.rationale: Viewing certain tasks as beneath oneself reflects grandiose entitlement.

items.text: People owe me a certain level of respect simply because of who I am.
items.rationale: Demanding respect as an inherent right rather than something earned is core Entitlement.

items.text: I become resentful when others receive privileges that I feel should be mine.
items.rationale: Resentment over others' privileges reflects the comparative nature of entitled thinking.

items.text: I think it's only fair that I get preferential treatment given my contributions.
items.rationale: Justifying preferential treatment through perceived contributions is a rationalized form of Entitlement.

items.text: I sometimes feel insulted when people don't immediately recognize my importance.
items.rationale: Feeling insulted by lack of recognition is primarily Entitlement but could also reflect Superiority beliefs.

items.text: I find it hard to accept criticism because I rarely think it's warranted.
items.rationale: Difficulty accepting criticism could stem from Entitlement but also from Superiority-based self-perception.

items.text: I deserve the best of everything—the best car, the best clothes, the best life.
items.rationale: While deserving the best is Entitlement, the focus on material possessions and appearance overlaps with Vanity.

items.text: I love being the center of attention at parties and social events.
items.rationale: Enjoying being the center of attention is the prototypical Exhibitionism item.

items.text: I will do almost anything to keep people's eyes on me.
items.rationale: Willingness to go to great lengths for attention is a strong Exhibitionism indicator.

items.text: I am happiest when I am performing or entertaining others.
items.rationale: Deriving happiness from performing for others directly taps Exhibitionism.

items.text: I like to show off my body and I'm not shy about it.
items.rationale: Comfort with and desire for physical display is a behavioral marker of Exhibitionism.

items.text: I get a thrill from having all eyes in the room focused on me.
items.rationale: Experiencing a thrill from attention reflects the emotional reward system underlying Exhibitionism.

items.text: I tend to be dramatic and expressive because I enjoy the reactions I get.
items.rationale: Using dramatic behavior to elicit reactions is a core behavioral expression of Exhibitionism.

items.text: If there's a stage or a spotlight, I want to be on it.
items.rationale: Seeking out performance opportunities directly maps to Exhibitionism.

items.text: I feel deflated and bored when nobody is paying attention to me.
items.rationale: Negative affect from lack of attention reflects dependence on external attention, a key Exhibitionism feature.

items.text: I enjoy telling stories about myself because I know people find me fascinating.
items.rationale: Self-focused storytelling driven by belief in one's fascination maps to Exhibitionism.

items.text: I have been told that I am a natural entertainer and I agree completely.
items.rationale: Self-identification as an entertainer validated by others is characteristic of Exhibitionism.

items.text: I often dress in ways that are designed to attract attention and admiration.
items.rationale: Using clothing strategically to attract attention is a behavioral expression of Exhibitionism.

items.text: I would rather be noticed for something outrageous than not noticed at all.
items.rationale: Preferring negative attention to no attention is a strong discriminating Exhibitionism item.

items.text: I post frequently on social media because I enjoy the likes and comments I receive.
items.rationale: Social media attention-seeking maps to Exhibitionism but is a modern behavior that could also reflect general social needs.

items.text: I make sure people notice when I've accomplished something impressive.
items.rationale: Ensuring others notice accomplishments is Exhibitionism but could also reflect Superiority through achievement display.

items.text: I enjoy being looked at and I make sure I always look my absolute best.
items.rationale: While enjoying being looked at is Exhibitionism, the emphasis on looking one's best overlaps significantly with Vanity.

items.text: I am good at getting people to do what I want them to do.
items.rationale: Skill at manipulating others' behavior is a core feature of Exploitativeness.

items.text: I don't mind using other people to get ahead if that's what it takes.
items.rationale: Willingness to use others instrumentally is the defining characteristic of Exploitativeness.

items.text: I can read people well and I use that ability to my advantage.
items.rationale: Using interpersonal perception strategically for personal gain maps directly to Exploitativeness.

items.text: I find it easy to manipulate situations so that things work out in my favor.
items.rationale: Self-reported ease of manipulation is a strong Exploitativeness indicator.

items.text: If someone has something I need, I'll figure out a way to get it from them.
items.rationale: Instrumental orientation toward others' resources is characteristic of Exploitativeness.

items.text: I sometimes flatter people not because I mean it, but because it gets me what I want.
items.rationale: Strategic use of insincere flattery is a classic exploitative interpersonal tactic.

items.text: People are essentially tools to be used for achieving my goals.
items.rationale: Viewing people instrumentally is the most direct expression of Exploitativeness.

items.text: I have a talent for turning other people's weaknesses into my opportunities.
items.rationale: Capitalizing on others' vulnerabilities is a hallmark of exploitative behavior.

items.text: I've been told I can be calculating in how I deal with people, and I take that as a compliment.
items.rationale: Embracing a calculating interpersonal style as positive reflects Exploitativeness.

items.text: I know exactly what to say to get people on my side, even if it's not entirely truthful.
items.rationale: Strategic deception for social influence is a core exploitative behavior.

items.text: I see relationships primarily in terms of what they can do for me.
items.rationale: Transactional view of relationships is a defining feature of Exploitativeness.

items.text: I have no problem taking credit for other people's work if it benefits me.
items.rationale: Taking undeserved credit is a concrete exploitative behavior.

items.text: I can usually talk my way out of any situation, no matter what I've done.
items.rationale: Verbal manipulation to avoid consequences is exploitative but could also reflect general social confidence or Authority.

items.text: I enjoy the challenge of persuading someone to change their mind to agree with me.
items.rationale: Enjoying persuasion could be Exploitativeness but also maps to Authority through influence and leadership.

items.text: I naturally take control of situations and guide people toward outcomes that serve my interests.
items.rationale: Taking control maps to Authority, but the self-serving motivation makes it exploitative. The boundary between directing others (Authority) and using them (Exploitativeness) is blurred here.

items.text: I can take care of myself without relying on anyone else.
items.rationale: Independence from others is the core of Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: I rarely need help from other people to accomplish my goals.
items.rationale: Belief in one's ability to achieve goals independently maps directly to Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: I prefer to rely on my own judgment rather than seek advice from others.
items.rationale: Preference for independent judgment over consultation is a key Self-Sufficiency indicator.

items.text: I am completely self-reliant and I wouldn't have it any other way.
items.rationale: Valuing and claiming total self-reliance is definitionally Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: Asking for help feels like admitting weakness, so I almost never do it.
items.rationale: Equating help-seeking with weakness reflects the narcissistic dimension of Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: I trust my own abilities more than I trust anyone else's.
items.rationale: Superior trust in one's own abilities over others' is a clear Self-Sufficiency marker.

items.text: I have always been able to figure things out on my own, even in tough situations.
items.rationale: Historical pattern of independent problem-solving reflects Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: I don't need other people's approval to feel confident in my decisions.
items.rationale: Independence from social approval in decision-making is a core Self-Sufficiency feature.

items.text: I would rather struggle alone than depend on someone else for support.
items.rationale: Preferring struggle over dependence reflects the extreme independence of Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: I believe I have everything I need within myself to succeed.
items.rationale: Belief in internal resources for success is a direct expression of Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: Other people's opinions don't really factor into my plans.
items.rationale: Dismissing others' input in planning reflects autonomous, self-sufficient orientation.

items.text: I've never felt like I truly needed anyone in my life to be happy.
items.rationale: Emotional independence and self-contained happiness map to Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: I handle pressure well because I know I can always count on myself.
items.rationale: Self-reliance under pressure is Self-Sufficiency but could also reflect general resilience or Authority-related confidence.

items.text: I don't follow trends or popular opinion—I make my own path.
items.rationale: Rejecting conformity maps to Self-Sufficiency but could also reflect Superiority through perceived uniqueness.

items.text: I know I can handle anything life throws at me because I am simply more capable than most people.
items.rationale: Self-reliance maps to Self-Sufficiency, but the explicit comparison to others and claim of greater capability overlaps with Superiority.

items.text: I am an extraordinary person who is destined for great things.
items.rationale: Belief in one's extraordinary nature and destiny is a prototypical Superiority item.

items.text: I honestly believe I am better than most people I meet.
items.rationale: Direct comparative self-enhancement is the defining feature of Superiority.

items.text: There is very little that someone could teach me that I don't already know.
items.rationale: Belief in one's comprehensive knowledge reflects intellectual superiority.

items.text: I consider myself to be a truly special and unique individual.
items.rationale: Self-perception as special and unique is a core Superiority belief.

items.text: Most people are simply not on my level intellectually or otherwise.
items.rationale: Explicit claim of being on a higher level than others is a strong Superiority indicator.

items.text: I think the world would be a better place if more people were like me.
items.rationale: Believing oneself to be a model for others reflects grandiose Superiority.

items.text: I have talents and qualities that set me apart from ordinary people.
items.rationale: Distinguishing oneself from 'ordinary' people is a hallmark of Superiority.

items.text: When I compare myself to others, I almost always come out on top.
items.rationale: Consistently favorable self-comparison is a direct measure of Superiority.

items.text: I have an exceptional mind and I know it.
items.rationale: Confident claim of exceptional intellect maps clearly to Superiority.

items.text: People who spend time with me are lucky because they get to be around someone truly remarkable.
items.rationale: Believing others are fortunate to be in one's presence reflects grandiose Superiority.

items.text: I can do most things better than the average person without even trying very hard.
items.rationale: Effortless superiority over others is a classic expression of the Superiority factor.

items.text: I know that I am special because everyone keeps telling me so.
items.rationale: Using social feedback to confirm special status reflects Superiority beliefs.

items.text: I sometimes feel frustrated that other people can't keep up with me.
items.rationale: Frustration with others' perceived inadequacy reflects Superiority but could also touch on Entitlement through frustrated expectations.

items.text: I have accomplished more in my life than most people ever will.
items.rationale: Achievement-based superiority is primarily Superiority but could also relate to Authority through accomplishment claims.

items.text: I deserve recognition for being exceptional, and it bothers me when I don't get it.
items.rationale: Believing one is exceptional is Superiority, but the demand for recognition and frustration at its absence overlaps with Entitlement.

items.text: I spend a lot of time on my appearance because I know how good I look.
items.rationale: Investment in appearance driven by positive self-assessment of looks is the core of Vanity.

items.text: I love looking at myself in the mirror—I really am attractive.
items.rationale: Pleasure in viewing one's own reflection with self-admiration is a prototypical Vanity item.

items.text: I know I am good looking because people tell me all the time.
items.rationale: Using social feedback to confirm physical attractiveness maps directly to Vanity.

items.text: My physical appearance is one of the things I am most proud of.
items.rationale: Pride centered on physical appearance is a defining feature of Vanity.

items.text: I think my face and body are close to perfect.
items.rationale: Grandiose self-assessment of physical perfection is a strong Vanity indicator.

items.text: I would be lying if I said I wasn't one of the most attractive people I know.
items.rationale: Comparative self-assessment of attractiveness with feigned modesty maps to Vanity.

items.text: I enjoy catching people staring at me because I know it's because of how I look.
items.rationale: Interpreting others' attention as admiration of one's appearance is characteristic of Vanity.

items.text: Looking good is extremely important to me and I invest heavily in my appearance.
items.rationale: High investment in appearance driven by its perceived importance maps to Vanity.

items.text: I take more selfies than most people because I genuinely think I look great in photos.
items.rationale: Frequent self-photography motivated by positive self-image is a modern behavioral expression of Vanity.

items.text: I have always been considered one of the best-looking people in any group I'm part of.
items.rationale: Consistent belief in being among the most attractive in social groups is a clear Vanity marker.

items.text: My looks have opened doors for me that wouldn't have opened otherwise.
items.rationale: Attributing life advantages to physical attractiveness reflects awareness and pride in appearance central to Vanity.

items.text: I feel confident that I am more physically attractive than most people around me.
items.rationale: Comparative confidence in one's attractiveness is a direct Vanity measure.

items.text: I check my reflection whenever I pass a mirror or window because I like what I see.
items.rationale: Habitual self-checking is primarily Vanity but could also reflect general self-consciousness or Exhibitionism.

items.text: I put a lot of effort into my grooming routine because I want people to notice how good I look.
items.rationale: Grooming for others' notice is Vanity but the desire for attention introduces some overlap with Exhibitionism.

items.text: I love it when people compliment my appearance—it makes me want to show off even more.
items.rationale: Compliments about appearance map to Vanity, but the desire to show off more in response overlaps with Exhibitionism.
